PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  A project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will assist the government in improving 
sector policies, preparing feasibility studies, and proposing a project design for a sector investment, 
and developing eligibility and evaluation criteria for selected subprojects.  
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The TA will assist the government update its sector policies, prepare two to three sample 
subprojects for a new water supply system and an expansion of an existing system), design a 
sector investment project, and develop eligibility and evaluation criteria for selected subprojects 
based on previous projects. The TA will explore new technologies, including energy efficient pumps 
and/or decentralized wastewater treatment. The TA will also support consultations with various 
stakeholders. The TA will be implemented over 12 months, from September 2012 to August 2013. 
The major outputs and activities are described and summarized in Table A4.1.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000 equivalent, of which $800,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). TASF financing is being 
requested, as stated in the Country Operations Business Plan for the Lao PDR, 2012–2015. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, provision of 
office space, and other in-kind contributions. Detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  A firm will be engaged in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). A total of 11 positions and 40 person-months required (6 
international specialists for 18 person-months and 5 national experts for 22 person-months). The 
firm will be recruited using quality and cost-based selection (90:10) using simplified technical 
proposal.15 Individual consultants may be hired during the TA to help complete unanticipated 
tasks and/or provide start-up support prior to loan effectiveness. The TA will adequately address 
the  following  aspects  relating  to  the  ensuing  project:  (i)  detailed  executing  agency,  and 
implementing agency capacity assessments, with remedial action plan to build executing agency 
and implementing agency capacity to minimize procurement and financial management risks; (ii) 
proposed  or  indicative  loan  related  procurement  plan  with  suggested  level  of  priority  or,  if 
applicable,  post  review  based  on  executing  agency  and  implementing  agency  capacity 
assessment; (iii)  indicative  implementation  schedule  with  proposed  sequencing  of  consultant 
recruitment and procurement bidding and awarding; (iv) a draft project performance management 
system; and (v) administration of seminars and workshops.  
5.  The terms of reference  are summarized in Table A4.3. The consultant team will be 
required to prepare the following reports: (i) inception report, 1.5 months after mobilization; (ii) 
interim report, 5 months after mobilization; (iii) draft final report, 7.0 months after mobilization; and 
(iv) final report, within 2 weeks after receipt of comments. The reports shall be of high quality and 
in formats agreed to in advance with ADB and the government. The team shall review previous 
feasibility studies prepared in the sector in Lao PDR, shall have an excellent command of the 
English  language,  shall  be  required  to  provide  their  inputs  to  the  team  leader  for  timely 
consolidation,  shall  coordinate  with  other  team  members,  and  may  be  asked  to  complete 
additional tasks as assigned by the consultant team leader and ADB project officer. 
                                                
15 A ratio of 90:10 will be used as the PPTA puts more emphasis on the quality rather than the cost.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
6.  The  executing  agency  for  the  TA  is  the  Ministry  of  Public  Works  and  Transport, 
specifically  the  Department  of  Housing  and  Urban  Planning  (DHUP).  The  current  project 
coordination unit in DHUP will provide guidance during TA implementation. This will ensure 
lessons from the ongoing projects are incorporated into the design of the proposed project. The 
government will provide in-kind contributions to the TA, including office space and counterpart 
staff. The TA consultants will be based in the PCU office in Vientiane. Disbursements under the 
TA will be done in accordance with the ADB Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2008, as amended from time to time) and procurement in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment procured by the TA will be will 
transferred to the Government (project coordination unit) at the end of the TA. 
7.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
